text: Apple Card: Unboxing & Review

Apple announced their very own credit credit
earlier this year at their services keynote

in March, and although it was initially only
released to select people through random invitations,

the card was officially released to the public
on August 20th.

Now in this video we’re going to take a
closer look at the physical card itself and

explore what makes the Apple Card different
from other credit cards, so you can decide
whether or not it’s right for you.

This is Greg with Apple Explained and if you
want to help decide which topics I cover,

make sure you’re subscribed and these voting
polls will show up in your mobile activity
feed.

Now before we take a look at the physical
card itself, I want to explain the concept

behind the Apple Card since it is quite different
from traditional credit cards.

Apple developed this card in partnership with
Goldman Sachs, the issuing bank, and Mastercard,
the payment network.

Apple put an emphasizing convenience with
their card, and that means delegating as many
responsibilities to the Wallet app as possible.

Applying for the card, receiving approval,
planning your payments, paying your bill,

tracking your spending, and receiving your
rewards all happens from within the Wallet
app.

This is important to understand since unlike
other credit cards, Apple doesn’t really
want you using their physical titanium card.

Instead, they want you to use the virtual
card with Apple Pay.

Now if you want to apply for the card, you’ll
do that by tapping the plus icon in the wallet
app and choosing Apple Card.

It’ll walk you through the application process
by asking for information like your name,
income, and social security number.

Then based on your credit history Goldman
Sachs will create on offer that you can either
accept or deny.

Now it’s important to note that there will
only be a hard pull on your credit if you
accept the offer.

Applying for an Apple Card will result in
a soft pull and won’t effect your credit.

You’ll need good to excellent credit to
be approved for the card, and if you are denied,
it may be a blessing in disguise.

Consider this: According to the US Federal
Reserve in 2016, 43% of Americans carried
credit card debt.

On which they were paying very high interest
rates of up to 25 or 30%, and this has trapped

many families in a never-ending cycle of debt
as interest piles up month after month.

But on the other hand, 57% of Americans always
pay off their credit card bill at the end
of the month.

So if you haven’t been approved for the
Apple Card but are confident in your financial

responsibility, check out the email you’ll
receive shortly after being denied.

There Goldman Sachs will give a reason for
your denial, and you can work on addressing
those issues before reapplying later on.

Now if you’re accepted, you’ll be assigned
a card number with a security code and expiration

date so you can begin using the virtual card
immediately, whether for online payments or
at stores that accept Apple Pay.

After Apple takes a few days creating your
card, it’ll be sent via Fedex priority overnight,

so you should receive your physical card within
24 hours of being shipped.

Your Apple Card will arrive in this Fedex
envelope which, once you open, contains Apple’s

own cardboard packaging to give the item some
extra protection.

There’s a convenient pull tab to open this
envelope, and then you’ll find this minimalist
white product packaging.

Simply lift the cover to reveal your very
own titanium Apple Card.

As you can see it doesn’t feature much information,
just my name, and that’s mainly for security
reasons.

But it’s also so you can generate a new
card number without the need to activate an
entirely new physical card.

Now the Apple Card is made from metal and
some of you guys wanted to hear what it sounded

like when thrown down, [sound] it’s actually
quite loud so I recommend simply handing to
the cashier.

Now when it comes to activation, all you have
to do is wake your phone and hold it near

the card’s packaging which contains an NFC
chip that’ll trigger this activation window.

Similar to how you might connect a pair of
AirPods.

Now if you lost or threw away the card’s
packaging, Apple does offer an alternative
method of activation.

So I was able to use this card for about a
week without any issues until something strange
happened.

Suddenly all of the transactions I tried making
with both the virtual and physical Apple Card
were blocked.

This alert appeared notifying me that my account
had been restricted and recommended that I
contact their support team, which I did.

This took me to the messages app where a new
text conversation was started with presumably

someone from Apple, who then transferred me
to an Apple Card Specialist at Goldman Sachs.

All of this was done through the messages
app within the same conversation, and I have

to admit the experience was quite seamless
and convenient.
But there was a problem.

An Apple Card Special was supposed to give
me a call shortly after our text conversation,
but that call never came.

And it didn’t come anytime in the following
three days either.

So I ended up messaging the Apple support
number again just to see if there were any
updates on the issue.

But the strange thing was the new specialist
receiving my messages wasn’t able to see

the previous correspondence I had three days
prior, despite all the texts showing up in
the same thread on my end.

So the new Apple Card Specialist asked me
for a case ID number from my previous conversation
with support.

But I’d never been received a number of
any kind from my initial text conversion,

and so I had to explain everything over again
to the new specialist.

Now the second time around things seemed to
be going quite a bit better since I wasn’t
immediately directed to make a call.

But after a half-hour of researching, I was
provided a phone number to contact Goldman
Sachs anyway.

I gave them a call, spent another 20 minutes
with their support team, and was notified

that I was under investigation by Goldman
Sachs to verify my identity.

They said I could mail them any documents
that I think might help them with the investigation.

I asked if a copy of my birth certificate
or social security card would be helpful,

but I was simply told, “whatever you think
might help with the investigation.”

Now that conversation happened last week,
and I’ve yet to hear back from Goldman Sachs.

So I’m not sure if I’ll be able to use
the Apple Card again anytime soon, but I’ll

just share my experience from the first week
of ownership.

I already mentioned how quick and easy it
was to apply for the card and start using

it, but that’s only a taste of the card’s
convenience.

It automatically appeared on my Apple Watch
for use with Apple Pay, and I could easily
set it as my primary card.

That way, I’d always be earning 2% cash
back on purchases through Apple Pay without
even thinking about it.

And that’s something I really love about
the Apple Card, it really is a set it and
forget it credit card solution.

Your monthly bill can automatically pay itself,
and your spending is automatically tracked
right from within the wallet app.

And this has been a huge time saver since
I typically spend hours manually entering

all of my monthly debit card transactions
in a spreadsheet.

If you have any technical issues like I did
and you need to contact support, being able

to text a specialist who responds almost immediately
is a huge convenience.

Also, if you lose your physical card, you
can simply lock it until you find it again,
or until Apple sends you a new one to activate.

If your identity is stolen and someone knows
your credit card number, all you have to do

is tap “Request New Card Number” without
the need to order a new physical card.

So clearly the Apple Card’s biggest strength
is its convenience and security features,

and I think those are what differentiates
it from traditional credit cards.

But when it comes to its rewards program,
the Apple Card is not as impressive.

You receive 3% cash back on purchases from
Apple like a new iPhone, an app, or a movie
from iTunes.
As well as purchases from Uber and Ubereats.

Now Apple said they’d be adding more merchants
to this 3% cash back tier in the near future,

so we’ll just have to wait and see who signs
on.

There’s also 2% cash back on all purchases
made with Apple Pay, and finally 1% cash back

on all purchases made with the physical Apple
Card.

I should also mention that there’s no signing
bonus.

So while the rewards program itself is average
at best, it is quite convenient since you

don’t have to wait until the end of the
month to receive your cash back.

The Apple Card features something called Daily
Cash.

Which means your Apple Cash balance is credited
with your cash back right when the transaction

goes through, and you can use that money on
a purchase or transfer it to your bank immediately.

But what might be even better than the rewards
program, is the fact that the Apple Card doesn’t
charge any fees.

There’s no late fees, no annual fees, no
over-limit fees, and no international fees.

I should also mention that if you have the
Apple Card and lose your iPhone, you’ll
have a hard time paying your bill.

Unless, of course, you’ve set up autopay
in which case the bill will pay itself whether
your iPhone is lost or not.

Otherwise, you’ll have to call Goldman Sachs
directly and pay your bill over the phone,
since there’s no way to pay online.

So if you’re someone who only uses credit
cards for the rewards and convenience isn’t

very important, then the Apple Card probably
isn’t for you.

But if you’re looking to replace your debit
card with something that earns you a little

bit of cash back and offers incredible security
and convenience features, then you’d probably
love having an Apple Card.

Something else you’d also love to have would
be Ting.
A mobile service that actually makes sense.

Because they charge you based on how much
data you use, instead of an arbitrary amount
every month.

When you call them for help or support, you
talk to a real person at no extra cost.
There’s no holds, no transfers, and no robots.

And since you only pay for what you use, the
average Ting bill is just $23 a month per
device.

Now if you’re stuck in a contract but would
like to switch to Ting, they’ll actually

cover 25% of your cancellation fee, up to
$75.

So head over to ae.ting.com, you can find
that link in the description, and try out
their bill estimator.

Enter how many minutes, texts, and how much
data you use on average based on your last

bill, and you can see how much you’d save
with Ting.

Then, when you sign up with our link, you’ll
receive a $25 credit toward your service bill
or a new device.
That link again is ae.ting.com.
